Award.AwardTitle: High Resolution Earth System Modeling for International Climate Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research between the University of Illinois and the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) is aimed at using the Blue Waters petascale resources to address key uncertainties associated with the numerical modeling of the Earth's climate system and the ability to accurately analyze past and projected future changes in climate. The project brings together a team of scientists to address these issues with well-recognized expertise in the study of past and future projections of climate and extensive experience in national and international assessments of climate change, as well as experts in computer science and information technology. The petascale computing capabilities will allow the project to pursue climate extremes and analysis of uncertainties in ways that were impossible before by allowing for completion of very high resolution atmosphere and ocean fully-coupled climate simulations, a task that requires a large computing allocation only achievable on petascale systems like Blue Waters.

This project has two purposes distinguished by the model resolution to be employed. Both climate model simulations will be conducted with an advanced version of the NSF-DOE Community Earth System Model (CESM). CESM, one of the world's best models of Earth's climate system, has been developed by NCAR in coordination with a community of scientists at universities and national laboratories. The first purpose is aimed at better quantifying future regional climate change, focusing on climate extremes, by running century-long, high-resolution (0.25 degree atmosphere/land, 1 degree ocean/sea ice) global coupled climate simulations, including multiple ensemble members of 20th Century and future scenarios. The second purpose will be specific studies that grow upon the project's existing Blue Water's allocation to further clarify the effects of small-scale regional features and interactions across spatial scales in climate through even higher-resolution climate simulations (0.25 degree atmosphere/land, 0.1 degree ocean/sea ice) that will push the state-of-the-art for such analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to address key uncertainties associated with the numerical modeling of the Earth’s climate system and the ability to accurately analyze past and projected future changes in climate. Specifically, we are investigating the representation of climate extremes within the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and how they may change in the future. To achieve this, we have conducted numerous climate simulations using various configurations of a high resolution version of the CESM. The high resolution allows us to capture these extreme events both spatially and temporally in a way that has been impossible before. Until having resources like Blue Waters, our ability to conduct such high resolution simulations for long, climate scenarios was limited. Using Blue Waters, we have now completed a significant portion containing various historical and future scenarios as well as ensemble members for the analysis of uncertainty.

 

The expectation in conducting climate simulations at higher resolution is not necessarily to improve the modeled mean climate state but to capture many aspects of extreme events and diurnal cycle patterns that cannot be resolved at lower resolution. Analysis thus far has shown that extreme precipitation is better represented when comparing precipitation from the high resolution atmosphere / low resolution ocean simulations to the nominal 1°simulations. Additionally, mesoscale convective systems (MCSs), which are responsible for much of the extreme precipitation over the continental U.S. are forming in the correct locations and propagating as expected across the continent in the runs using the 0.25°atmosphere compared to the 1°atmosphere simulations. These two results are encouraging for our follow-on studies into atmospheric rivers, tropical and midlatitude storms, and extreme precipitation events over land. Over the past year, we have also found the statistics of atmospheric rivers to better match observations within this set of runs than the in the coarser 1°simulations. Additionally, the high resolution atmosphere and ocean simulations exhibit marked improvement in the position of western boundary currents, such as the Gulf Stream, a common problem in lower resolution models. Also related to the Gulf Stream is a trend of sea surface temperature off the northeast coast of the U.S. that is much higher than the global mean. This has been well documented within observations. This trend is not present in the nominal 1°model configuration but is found within the simulations using the 0.1°ocean, which is very encouraging for future work.

 

The completion of these high resolution simulations have great significance both to our group as well as the CESM community. The set of high resolution atmosphere and ocean simulations complete the very first set of simulations with this particular resolution including the first future scenario. The set of high resolution atmosphere coupled to a lower resolution ocean are the first of their kind with the CESM1.3 code and are the first full set of simulations including various scenarios and ensemble members. A high resolution version of the CESM2, which was released in mid-2018, is not expected for another year, and therefore, we expect these simulations to be widely used by the community.
